security_audit.summary: This skill contains only markdown documentation with no executable code. It provides git workflow guidance and conventions without any file system access, network requests, or command execution capabilities.

content.user_title: Master Git Branch and Commit Workflows
content.value_statement: Developers waste time on inconsistent branch names and commit messages. This skill enforces standardized git workflows with automatic branch validation, conventional commit formatting, and PR checklist guidance.
actual_capabilities: Validate branch names against naming conventions
Prepare conventional commit messages with proper formatting
Generate pull request descriptions from commit history
Check repository health and branch status
Map branch prefixes to semantic versioning impacts
Enforce consistent commit and branch patterns across teams
limitations: Does not execute git commands directly on the system
Requires user to manually run validated commands
Does not integrate with git hosting platforms (GitHub, GitLab)
Cannot push or pull from remote repositories

use_cases.title: Personal Git Hygiene
use_cases.description: Maintain clean commit history and branch names for personal projects

use_cases.title: Team Workflow Enforcement
use_cases.description: Ensure all team members follow consistent branch and commit conventions

use_cases.title: PR Quality Checks
use_cases.description: Validate pull requests meet project standards before review

prompt_templates.title: Check Branch Status
prompt_templates.prompt: Check my current git branch and validate it follows naming conventions. Show the branch type and describe any issues.

prompt_templates.title: Create Feature Branch
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create a properly named feature branch for adding user authentication. What commands do I need to run?

prompt_templates.title: Write Commit Message
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me write a conventional commit message for fixing the login bug. Include type, scope, description, body, and footer.

prompt_templates.title: Prepare PR Description
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a pull request description for my feature branch. Summarize the changes, list modified files, and create a testing checklist.

output_examples.input: Validate my current branch follows naming conventions
output: This branch follows the conventional format correctly

best_practices: Always create feature branches from main/develop, never commit directly
Use descriptive branch names that explain the change purpose
Write commit messages that explain why, not just what changed
Link commits and PRs to issue tracking systems
anti_patterns: Working directly on main or master branches
Using vague branch names like fix1, fix2, or update
Writing commits that only say fixed bug or updated code
Merging without reviewing the commit history first

faq.question: Which git platforms does this skill support?
faq.answer: Works with GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket, and any git-based repository. The skill provides commands that work with any git host.

faq.question: What branch naming formats are supported?
faq.answer: Supports {type}/{slug} format with types: feat, fix, docs, refactor, perf, test, chore, and hotfix.

faq.question: How does this integrate with my IDE?
faq.answer: The skill provides git commands you run in your terminal. It does not directly integrate with IDEs but works alongside them.

faq.question: Is my repository data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill only provides guidance and documentation. It never reads, writes, or modifies your repository without your explicit action.

faq.question: Why are my branch names being rejected?
faq.answer: Branches must follow the {type}/{descriptive-slug} pattern. Common issues include missing type prefix, using uppercase letters, or special characters.

faq.question: How is this different from git CLI?
faq.answer: The git CLI executes commands. This skill guides you on when and how to use git properly. It enforces conventions rather than replacing git.
